content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" may impose sanctions for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, including civil penalties. Sec. 109 of the "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits royalty violations, including failure to comply with requirements, make required royalty payments, or submit false information related to royalty payments. Sec. 109 of the "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" prohibits royalty violations, including failure to comply with requirements, make required royalty payments, or submit false information related to royalty payments. Violators may face penalties of up to 3 times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, and a civil penalty of $25,000 per violation per day. The text outlines penalties for royalty payment violations, including a civil penalty of $25,000 per violation per day. It also specifies that violations can be exempted if reported and corrected within 30 days. Additionally, it addresses lease administration violations such as failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments, and refusal to permit lawful entry. Failure to comply with lease management responsibilities, including failure to permit lawful entry, inspection, or audit, and failure to report necessary records, may result in a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Failure to comply with lease management responsibilities, such as theft of oil or gas, may result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day for unauthorized actions and up to $25,000 per violation per day for theft or unlawful activities. Repeated violations of subsections (a), (b), or (c) may result in a civil penalty equal to 3 times the original amount, in addition to the initial penalty. Compliance must be achieved within 30 days of notification by the Secretary or designee. The Secretary may impose penalties up to 3 times the original amount for repeated violations of subsections (a), (b), or (c). Additional actions may include shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring lease interests, and collecting reimbursement from the violator. The Secretary has the authority to impose penalties for violations of lease agreements, including cancelling or transferring lease interests and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred. Administrative appeals can be filed within 15 days of notification of the amount owed. The Secretary can impose penalties for lease violations, with the option to file an administrative appeal within 15 days. The final penalty amount can be deducted from any sums owed by the person charged. The Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail. The Secretary can impose penalties for lease violations, with the option to file an administrative appeal within 15 days. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail. Any person aggrieved by a final order of the Secretary may seek review in the United States district court. Any person prescribed for a hearing and aggrieved by the Secretary's final order can seek review in the United States district court within 90 days. Failure to pay a civil penalty may result in the court awarding the amount assessed. After a court judgment in favor of the Secretary, the court can award the assessed amount plus interest. No civil penalty for failure to pay rental for a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Violations toll statutes of limitations for oil and gas leases. The Secretary or their designee can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases if a person violates certain subsections until the violation is corrected or a final order is issued. The person must also maintain all records related to their oil and gas leases until released from this obligation by the Secretary. The Secretary can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases if a violation occurs until it is corrected or a final order is issued. The person must maintain all records related to their leases until released from this obligation by the Secretary. Amounts received from penalties in actions for underpayment of royalties are treated as royalties paid to the United States under the lease. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amendment to the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 to increase penalties for violations.
